newsitem.title: GERMANY: Collectors foil Euro experiment in German town.
newsitem.headline: Collectors foil Euro experiment in German town.

text.p: An attempt by a small German town to give its citizens a taste of the future single European currency failed because coin collectors were more interested in keeping the coins than spending them, the town's mayor said on Sunday.

Waldkirch Mayor Richard Leibinger said the city's 20,000 citizens had little chance to spend the "Euro" that was put into circulation for a two-week period in the small Black Forest town because collectors had hoarded the coins.

"It didn't turn out as we had hoped," Leibinger told Bild am Sonntag newspaper. "Two hours after we started all the coins were gone. We had coin collectors calling from around the world wanting the coins."

Waldkirch, a picturesque town near Freiburg in southwestern Germany, made available some 6,000 Euro coins, which could be "exchanged" at a local savings bank at the rate of two marks ($1.31) per Euro.

The 1,000 Euro coins with a face value of 25 Euros and the 6,000 3-Euro coins were all snapped up on the first day, Leibinger said. About 50 stores in the town were ready to accept the Euro as a parallel currency to the mark, but never got the chance to make change in Euros. ($1=1.5293 Mark)
